The respiratory system aids in breathing, also called pulmonary ventilation. Air is inhaled through the nose and mouth, moves through the pharynx, larynx, and trachea into the lungs, and is exhaled the same way. Changes in lung volume and air pressure drive this process.
Muscles of the thorax that elevate the ribs, aiding in normal inspiration. Their fibers run obliquely downward and laterally (back) or forward and medialward (front).
Thoracic muscles that depress the ribs, aiding in forced expiration. Their fibers run opposite to those of the external intercostals.
The principal muscle of inspiration that separates the thoracic and abdominal cavities, expanding the thoracic cavity and compressing the abdominal cavity.
The diaphragm and external intercostals contract, elevating the ribcage. Lung volume increases, pressure drops, and air flows in.
Muscles like the sternocleidomastoid, scalenes, pectoralis minor, and serratus anterior contract to assist deeper breathing.
The diaphragm and external intercostals relax. Lung volume decreases, pressure increases, and air is expelled.
Internal intercostals, transversus thoracis, and abdominal muscles contract to push out air more forcefully.
Internal chambers of the nose that warm, moisten, and filter inhaled air. Air enters through the nares and exits into the nasopharynx.
Cartilage and connective tissue that divide the nasal cavity into left and right halves.
Air-filled cavities in skull bones (frontal, ethmoidal, sphenoidal, maxillary) that warm and humidify inhaled air.
A muscular tube divided into the nasopharynx, oropharynx, and laryngopharynx; it conducts air from the nasal/oral cavities to the larynx and trachea.
A structure connecting the pharynx to the trachea, serving as an open airway and voice box. It plays a key role in breathing and sound production.
A neck bone that supports the larynx and provides attachment for muscles involved in swallowing and speech.
Elastic structures in the larynx that vibrate to produce sound; pitch changes with muscle-regulated tension.
A leaf-shaped cartilage that covers the larynx during swallowing, preventing food from entering the airway.
A cartilaginous tube that conducts air between the larynx and bronchi, allowing inhalation and exhalation.
C-shaped cartilage structures that keep the trachea open, allowing flexibility and preventing collapse.
Organs of gas exchange, with the right lung having three lobes and the left two (with a cardiac notch). They exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide with the blood.
Double-layered membranes surrounding the lungs. The pleural cavity between them contains lubricating fluid to reduce friction during breathing.
Mesenteric folds extending from the lung root to the mediastinum, helping stabilize the lung in the thoracic cavity.

involuntary muscle tissue found only in the heart. Job is to pump blood
striated and voluntary muscle tissue attached to the skeleton. Job is voluntary movement and to create heat

A nerve cell that transmits electrical impulses throughout the body.
The long, slender projection of a neuron that conducts electrical impulses away from the neuron's cell body.
The branched projections of a neuron that receive signals from other neurons.
The junction between two neurons where information is transmitted.
Chemicals that transmit signals across a synapse from one neuron to another.
Comprises the brain and spinal cord, responsible for processing and sending out information.
Consists of nerves and ganglia outside the CNS, connecting it to limbs and organs.
A subdivision of the PNS that controls involuntary body functions like heartbeat and digestion.
A subdivision of the PNS that controls voluntary movements of skeletal muscles.
The largest part of the brain, responsible for voluntary activities, intelligence, memory, and sensory processing.
The part of the brain that coordinates muscle movements and maintains posture and balance.
Connects the brain to the spinal cord and controls vital life functions such as breathing and heartbeat.
The lower part of the brainstem that controls autonomic functions like breathing and heart rate.
A long, thin, tubular structure that connects the brain to the rest of the body, transmitting nerve signals.
A fatty layer that covers axons, increasing the speed of nerve impulse transmission.
The neural pathway that mediates a reflex action.
Nerve cells that carry impulses from sensory receptors to the CNS.
Nerve cells that carry impulses from the CNS to muscles or glands.
Neurons that connect sensory and motor neurons within the CNS.
A rapid rise and subsequent fall in voltage or membrane potential across a cellular membrane.
The electrical potential of a neuron when not transmitting a signal.
The process during which the neuron's membrane potential becomes less negative.
The process of restoring the resting potential after depolarization.
An increase in a cell's membrane potential, making it more negative.
The level of stimulation required to trigger a neural impulse.
The concept that a neuron either fires completely or does not fire at all.
The time following an action potential during which a neuron is unable to fire again.
Gaps in the myelin sheath that facilitate rapid conduction of nerve impulses.
The process by which nerve impulses jump from one node of Ranvier to the next.
Regions of the CNS rich in neuronal cell bodies.
Regions of the CNS rich in myelinated axons.
The three protective membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord.
A clear fluid that cushions the brain and spinal cord.
A selective barrier that prevents certain substances from entering the brain.
Non-neuronal cells that provide support and protection for neurons.
Star-shaped glial cells that maintain the blood-brain barrier and provide nutrients to neurons.
Glial cells in the CNS that produce the myelin sheath.
Glial cells in the PNS that produce the myelin sheath.
Glial cells that act as the main form of active immune defense in the CNS.
Glial cells that line the ventricles of the brain and produce CSF.
Twelve pairs of nerves that emerge directly from the brain.
Nerves that emerge from the spinal cord.
A cluster of nerve cell bodies in the PNS.
A network of intersecting nerves.
Part of the ANS that prepares the body for 'fight or flight' responses.
Part of the ANS that conserves energy and restores the body to resting state.
A subdivision of the ANS that governs the function of the gastrointestinal system.
The brain's ability to reorganize itself by forming new neural connections.
The process of generating new neurons.
The tendency for some neural functions to be more dominant in one hemisphere than the other.
A bundle of nerve fibers connecting the two cerebral hemispheres.
The part of the cerebrum involved in decision making, problem solving, and planning.
The part of the cerebrum that processes sensory information.
The part of the cerebrum involved in processing auditory information and memory.
The part of the cerebrum responsible for visual processing.
A complex system of nerves involved in emotions and memory.
A structure in the limbic system associated with memory formation.
A structure in the limbic system involved in emotion processing.
The brain's relay station for sensory information.
A region that controls autonomic functions and links the nervous system to the endocrine system.
The 'master gland' that regulates other endocrine glands.
A small gland that produces melatonin, regulating sleep cycles.
A group of nuclei involved in movement regulation.
A brain structure involved in movement and reward.
A network of neurons involved in arousal and consciousness.
A region in the frontal lobe associated with speech production.
